title: Panna National Park
short_description: A resounding success story of tiger reintroduction, situated along the Ken River.
long_description: Panna National Park is located in Panna and Chhatarpur districts of Madhya Pradesh in India. It has an area of 542.67 km2. It was declared in 1994 as the twenty-second Tiger Reserve of India and the fifth in Madhya Pradesh. Panna was known for its lack of tigers in 2009 due to poaching, but thanks to a highly successful relocation program from Bandhavgarh and Kanha, it now boasts a healthy tiger population. The Ken River, which flows through the park, creates spectacular scenery including waterfalls and is home to the Mugger and Gharial crocodiles. The park is also famous for its 7 vulture species.
wildlife_significance: Successful tiger reintroduction program. Home to significant Vulture populations and Gharials.
major_experiences: Boat Ride on Ken River to see crocodiles
guides_and_tips: Combine your trip with Khajuraho temples (25 km away). Boat safari is a must-do.
how_to_reach: By Air: Khajuraho Airport (25 km). By Rail: Satna (70 km) or Khajuraho.
permits_and_fees: Book permits online via MP Online Forest portal.
conservation_notes: Vulture census and conservation program is active here.
sample_itinerary: Day 1: Arrive Khajuraho, drive to Panna. Evening Boat Safari. Day 2: Morning Jeep Safari. Visit Pandav Falls. Afternoon Safari. Day 3: Visit Raneh Falls. Drive to Khajuraho for temple tour. Departure.
safety_tips: Rocky terrain; hold on tight during safaris. Do not swim in Ken River (crocodiles).
